div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 5 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.
The Egyptian Gazette An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880. Editor Manager P. Smelling. Price One Piastre Tariff. MONDAY, JANUARY 16, 1905.

RAILWAY RETURN TICKETS We notice that several of our contemporaries assert that return tickets are to be re-introduced on the Egyptian State Railways. Their Absence is one of the many things that may have struck the members of the recent Railway Commission, and may have been remarked upon by them, any knowledge of which (may be held to be sufficient ground for stating that the want will be immediately supplied. These tickets were in force in former times and abolished because of the openings they afforded for their fraudulent use. Things are more orderly now, but on the other hand, the passenger traffic is heavier to deal with, and generally speaking, we do not see on the Egyptian State Railways the existence of those precautions necessary to control crowds of passengers. Until provision for these is made we shall be surprised if return tickets are introduced-it would only be courting failure.

THE SUEZ CANAL The new Suez Canal proposals may be only a threat, and the scheme may be impracticable, but it has certainly creaated a stir among the governing body of the Canal. A considerable amount of correspondence bearing on the question has passed between Egypt and Paris, with the result that four members of the head administration, two French, one British, and one Dutch, have arrived at Port-Said, and are busily engaged, amongst other things, in inspecting the new harbour works, in the company M. Tillier, director-general from Cairo, and M. Coulant, director at Port-Said. It is much to be regretted that the Canal Company cannot see their way to give some public indication of the nature of their scheme. From an outsidder's point of view, the progress of the works appears to be so slow, and the plant and personnel are so trivial for such a gigantic piece of work, that no real por extension seems likely to be accomplished for many years. One would think that the present rate of development of the country, and the congested state of the port of Alexandria, would warrant the company’s tackling this large scheme in a more serious and energetic manner.

TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS. FORT ARTHUR FORMAL ENTRY OF JAPS. SURRENDER INEXPLICABLE. PORT ARTHUR, JANUARY 14. The Japanese have formally entered Port Arthur. Detachments of all arms are marching to the sound of the bugle in the old and new towns. (Reuter) TOKIO, January 14. The surrender of Port Arthur is inexplicable because there were no signs of privation. The prisoners number upwards of 24,000, excluding the sick and wounded. (Reuter.)

TSAR AND PORT ARTHUR CONFIDENCE IN THE FUTURE St. Petersburg, January 14. The Tsar in an order of the day to the Army and Navy announcing the fall of Port Arthur, eulogizes the glorious garrison whose heroism Russia has witnessed with pride. The order adds: “Peace he to the ashes of the dead, and glory to the living. Our enemy is bold and strong. The struggle at such a distance is indescribably hard, but Russia is powerful, and has undergone harder trials in the past from which she always emerged more powerful. While lamenting our losses, we must not become distracted. With all Russia, I trust that the hour of victory will soon dawn and I pray God to bless our troops and fleets so that they may be able to uphold the glory of Russia.” (Reuter.) ST. PETERSBURG, January 14. An order of the day by the Tsar praises the heroic defence of Port Arthur and foresees the early triumph of Russia. (Havas.)
GENERAL STOESSEL RECEPTION AT NAGASAKI Nagasaki, January 14. General Stoessel arrived here in the afternoon. The Governor, with a guard of honor, welcomed him.
